title: Chapter 1: Energy Resources and Conservation
subject: Science

questions.question: When you drop a ball, some energy becomes heat due to air resistance. What happens to the ball's final kinetic energy?
options: It equals the initial gravitational potential energy
It is less than the initial gravitational potential energy
It is more than the initial gravitational potential energy
questions.explanation: Some GPE converts to heat due to air resistance, so final KE is less than initial GPE. Energy is conserved but some becomes unwanted heat.

questions.question: Why can't a machine be 100% efficient?
options: Some energy always converts to heat due to friction
questions.explanation: Friction in moving parts converts some useful energy to thermal energy (heat), reducing efficiency.

questions.question: A car engine converts chemical energy from fuel. Where does most of the 'lost' energy go?
questions.explanation: Car engines are only 20-30% efficient. Most fuel energy becomes heat in the engine and exhaust.

questions.question: When you push a box across a rough floor, why do you get tired even if the box moves at constant speed?
options: Work done becomes gravitational potential energy
Work done against friction converts to heat
questions.explanation: Work done against friction converts to thermal energy (heat), not useful kinetic or potential energy.

questions.question: Which energy source is renewable and produces minimal heat waste during electricity generation?
questions.explanation: All energy conversions produce some heat waste due to friction, electrical resistance, etc.

questions.question: If you do 100J of work lifting a box, but only 80J becomes gravitational potential energy, where did 20J go?
options: Became heat in your muscles and surroundings
questions.explanation: Your muscles aren't 100% efficient. Some energy becomes body heat during muscle contraction.

questions.question: Why does a bouncing ball eventually stop?
options: Each bounce converts some kinetic energy to heat and sound
questions.explanation: Energy converts to heat from air resistance and sound with each bounce reducing kinetic energy.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of renewable energy sources over fossil fuels?
options: They produce no greenhouse gases during operation
questions.explanation: Renewables like solar/wind/hydro don't emit CO₂ during electricity generation, though all produce some heat waste.

questions.question: When a car brakes, what happens to its kinetic energy?
options: Mostly converts to heat in brake pads
questions.explanation: Friction between brake pads and discs converts kinetic energy to thermal energy (heat).

questions.question: Which statement about energy conservation is CORRECT?
options: Total energy always decreases due to heat loss
Useful output energy equals input energy
Energy converts to different forms but total remains constant
Heat is the only form energy can take
questions.explanation: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted between forms. Heat is one form energy can take.

questions.question: Why are LED bulbs more efficient than incandescent bulbs?
options: They convert more electricity to light, less to heat
They use different type of electricity
They are brighter at same wattage
questions.explanation: LEDs convert ~80-90% of electrical energy to light vs ~10% for incandescent (rest becomes heat).

questions.question: When you rub your hands together, what energy conversion occurs?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy of motion converts to thermal energy through friction, warming your hands.

questions.question: What is a limitation of solar energy?
options: Panels convert all sunlight to electricity
questions.explanation: Solar panels don't generate electricity at night, and some sunlight becomes heat rather than electricity.

questions.question: In a pendulum, why does the swing height decrease over time?
options: Energy converts to heat from air resistance and friction
questions.explanation: Air resistance and friction at pivot convert work done to thermal energy hence reducing the swing height.

questions.question: Which fossil fuel produces most CO₂ per unit of energy?
questions.explanation: Coal produces most CO₂, followed by oil, then natural gas produces least among fossil fuels.

learning_objectives: Distinguish renewable and non-renewable energy sources
Explain energy loss as heat in conversions
Identify where 'lost' energy goes in systems
key_concepts: Energy conserved but converts to different forms
Friction causes energy loss as heat
